meta.title: Current Affairs MCQs
meta.description: Multiple choice questions on recent events and developments in Pakistan and around the world.
meta.keywords: Current Affairs, Pakistan, International, Politics, Economy, Society, World Events

questions.q: What is the current status of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)?

questions.q: What is the currency of Pakistan?

questions.q: Which river is the longest in Pakistan?

questions.q: What is the minimum age to vote in Pakistan?

questions.q: Which Pakistani city is known as the 'City of Gardens'?

questions.q: Who designed the national flag of Pakistan?

questions.q: What is the traditional dress for men in many parts of Pakistan?

questions.q: Which pass connects Pakistan and China?

questions.q: What is the significance of the Resolution of Lahore (Pakistan Resolution)?
options: It demanded a separate homeland for Muslims of British India.
It called for independence from British rule.
It established the first political party.
questions.ex: The Resolution of Lahore, passed in 1940, was a formal political statement by the All-India Muslim League calling for a separate homeland for the Muslims of British India.

questions.q: Which Pakistani province has the longest coastline?
questions.ex: Balochistan province has the longest coastline in Pakistan.

questions.q: What is the main judicial body of Pakistan?
questions.ex: The Supreme Court of Pakistan is the apex court in the judicial hierarchy.

questions.q: What is the current literacy rate in Pakistan (approximate)?
questions.ex: The literacy rate in Pakistan is generally estimated to be between 60% and 70%.

questions.q: Which Pakistani dam is the largest in terms of water storage capacity?
questions.ex: Tarbela Dam on the Indus River is the largest earth-filled dam in the world and has the largest water storage capacity in Pakistan.

questions.q: What is the primary function of the National Accountability Bureau (NAB) in Pakistan?
questions.ex: The National Accountability Bureau (NAB) is Pakistan's anti-corruption organization.

questions.q: Which international organization is Pakistan a founding member of?
questions.ex: Pakistan is a founding member of the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC).

questions.q: Who is the current Secretary-General of the United Nations?

questions.q: Which country currently holds the presidency of the G20?

questions.q: What is the name of the current Director-General of the World Health Organization (WHO)?
questions.ex: Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus is the current Director-General of the WHO.

questions.q: Which city hosted the most recent COP (Conference of the Parties) climate summit?
questions.ex: COP28 was held in Dubai, UAE.

questions.q: What is the primary focus of the International Monetary Fund (IMF)?
questions.ex: The IMF's primary goal is to ensure global monetary cooperation, secure financial stability, facilitate international trade, promote high employment and sustainable economic growth, and reduce poverty.

questions.q: Which country recently joined NATO as its newest member?
questions.ex: Sweden recently became the newest member of NATO.

questions.q: What is the name of the current President of the European Commission?

questions.q: Which major international event was significantly impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020?

questions.q: What is the main objective of the World Trade Organization (WTO)?

questions.q: Which country is currently experiencing a major humanitarian crisis due to conflict?

questions.q: What is the name of the international agreement aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions?
questions.ex: The Paris Agreement is a legally binding international treaty on climate change.

questions.q: Which international court deals with genocide, war crimes, and crimes against humanity?
questions.ex: The International Criminal Court (ICC) investigates and, where warranted, tries individuals charged with the gravest crimes of concern to the international community.

questions.q: What is the significance of the Belt and Road Initiative?
questions.ex: The Belt and Road Initiative is a global infrastructure development strategy adopted by the Chinese government to invest in more than 150 countries and international organizations.

questions.q: Which international organization is responsible for global financial stability?
questions.ex: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is a key organization for promoting international financial stability.

questions.q: What is the term for a widespread occurrence of an infectious disease in a community at a particular time?
questions.ex: An epidemic is a widespread occurrence of an infectious disease in a community at a particular time.

questions.q: Which country was the host of the most recent Winter Olympic Games?
questions.ex: Beijing, China hosted the most recent Winter Olympic Games in 2022.

questions.q: What is the primary goal of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)?
options: To achieve a better and more sustainable future for all
To regulate global currency exchange rates

questions.q: Which international body is responsible for coordinating efforts against terrorism?
questions.ex: The United Nations Counter-Terrorism Centre (UNCCT) plays a significant role in coordinating global counter-terrorism efforts.

questions.q: What is the name of the current President of the World Bank?

questions.q: Which country has been significantly affected by the ongoing conflict in the Tigray region?
questions.ex: The Tigray region is part of Ethiopia, and the conflict there has caused a major humanitarian crisis.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the UN Security Council?
options: To maintain international peace and security
questions.ex: The UN Security Council has primary responsibility for the maintenance of international peace and security.

questions.q: Which region has been significantly impacted by the Sahel crisis?
questions.ex: The Sahel region is in Sub-Saharan Africa and faces significant challenges including conflict, poverty, and climate change.

questions.q: What is the name of the international treaty on the conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity?
questions.ex: The Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) is an international treaty signed at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro in 1992.

questions.q: Which international organization focuses on nuclear safety and security?
questions.ex: The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) is the world's centre for cooperation in the nuclear field.

questions.q: What is the primary driver of recent global inflation?
options: Supply chain disruptions and energy prices
questions.ex: Recent global inflation has been largely attributed to supply chain disruptions, increased energy prices, and post-pandemic economic recovery.

questions.q: Which country is a permanent member of the UN Security Council?
questions.ex: France is one of the five permanent members of the UN Security Council.

questions.q: What is the term for the forced displacement of people from their homes?
questions.ex: A refugee crisis refers to a situation involving the large-scale forced displacement of people.

questions.q: Which international agreement deals with the law of the sea?
options: Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties
United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS)
questions.ex: UNCLOS is an international treaty that establishes a legal framework for all marine and maritime activities.

questions.q: What is the main focus of Amnesty International?
questions.ex: Amnesty International is a non-governmental organization focused on human rights.

questions.q: Which country is a key member of the BRICS economic bloc?
questions.ex: Brazil is a founding member of the BRICS economic bloc (Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa).

questions.q: Who is the current Prime Minister of Pakistan?
questions.ex: As of recent times, Shehbaz Sharif has served as the Prime Minister of Pakistan.

questions.q: What is the upper house of Pakistan's Parliament called?
questions.ex: The Senate is the upper legislative chamber of the Parliament of Pakistan.

questions.q: Which political party currently holds the majority in the National Assembly of Pakistan?
questions.ex: The Pakistan Muslim League (N) (PML-N) has held significant power in recent governments.

questions.q: Who is the current President of Pakistan?
questions.ex: Asif Ali Zardari is currently the President of Pakistan.

questions.q: What is the minimum age to be eligible to vote in Pakistan?
questions.ex: The minimum voting age in Pakistan is 18 years.

questions.q: Which provincial assembly is the largest in Pakistan?
questions.ex: The Punjab Assembly has the highest number of seats among Pakistan's provincial assemblies.

questions.q: What is the duration of a term for the National Assembly in Pakistan?
questions.ex: A term for the National Assembly of Pakistan is five years.

questions.q: Who was the first Prime Minister of Pakistan?
questions.ex: Liaquat Ali Khan was the first Prime Minister of Pakistan.

questions.q: What is the head of state in Pakistan called?
questions.ex: The President is the head of state in Pakistan.

questions.q: What is the supreme judicial body of Pakistan?
questions.ex: The Supreme Court of Pakistan is the apex court in the judicial hierarchy.

questions.q: Which city serves as the capital of Pakistan?
questions.ex: Islamabad is the capital city of Pakistan.

questions.q: What is the system of government in Pakistan?
questions.ex: Pakistan has a federal parliamentary republic system of government.

questions.q: What is the total number of seats in the National Assembly of Pakistan (excluding reserved seats)?
questions.ex: The total number of general seats in the National Assembly is 272.

questions.q: What is the minimum age to be a member of the National Assembly in Pakistan?
questions.ex: The minimum age to be a member of the National Assembly is 25 years.

questions.q: Which constitutional amendment in Pakistan restored the parliamentary system and curtailed presidential powers?
questions.ex: The 18th Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan significantly curtailed presidential powers and restored the parliamentary system.

questions.q: Who was the first female Prime Minister of Pakistan?
questions.ex: Benazir Bhutto was the first female Prime Minister of Pakistan.

questions.q: What is the name of the treaty that demarcates the border between Pakistan and Afghanistan?
questions.ex: The Durand Line is the 2,670 kilometer border between Afghanistan and Pakistan.

questions.q: Which year did Pakistan conduct its first successful nuclear tests?
questions.ex: Pakistan conducted its first successful nuclear tests (Chagai-I) in 1998.

questions.q: What is the role of the Election Commission of Pakistan (ECP)?
questions.ex: The Election Commission of Pakistan is an independent, autonomous, permanent and constitutional body responsible for organizing and conducting elections.

questions.q: Who is the Commander-in-Chief of the Pakistan Armed Forces?
questions.ex: The President of Pakistan is the Commander-in-Chief of the Pakistan Armed Forces.

questions.q: What is the name of Pakistan's intelligence agency?
questions.ex: The Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI) is the premier intelligence agency of Pakistan.

questions.q: What is the official name of the Parliament of Pakistan?
questions.ex: The Parliament of Pakistan is officially known as Majlis-e-Shura.

questions.q: Which bill aims to protect women against harassment in Pakistan?
options: Protection against Harassment of Women at the Workplace Act
questions.ex: The Protection against Harassment of Women at the Workplace Act, 2010, is a key law in this regard.

questions.q: What is the primary function of the National Accountability Bureau (NAB) in Pakistan?
questions.ex: The National Accountability Bureau (NAB) is Pakistan's autonomous and constitutionally established federal institution responsible to combat corruption and investigate.

questions.q: What is the role of the Leader of the Opposition in the National Assembly of Pakistan?
questions.ex: The Leader of the Opposition plays a crucial role in scrutinizing government policies and providing an alternative viewpoint.

questions.q: Which province of Pakistan has the largest area?
questions.ex: Balochistan is the largest province of Pakistan by area.

questions.q: What is the role of the Attorney General for Pakistan?
options: Principal legal advisor to the government
questions.ex: The Attorney General for Pakistan is the chief legal advisor to the Government of Pakistan.

questions.q: Which is the longest-serving political party in Pakistan?
questions.ex: The Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) has been a prominent political force in Pakistan for a significant period.

questions.q: What is the primary objective of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)?
questions.ex: CPEC is a collection of infrastructure projects under construction throughout Pakistan, aiming to boost economic growth.

questions.q: Who was the first military ruler of Pakistan?
questions.ex: Ayub Khan was the first military ruler and second President of Pakistan.

questions.q: What is the significance of the 23rd March in Pakistan's political history?
questions.ex: 23rd March is celebrated as Pakistan Resolution Day, commemorating the adoption of the Lahore Resolution.

questions.q: What is the current number of administrative units (provinces and territories) in Pakistan?
questions.ex: Pakistan consists of four provinces (Punjab, Sindh, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Balochistan) and two autonomous territories (Azad Jammu and Kashmir, Gilgit-Baltistan).

questions.q: Who is the current Secretary-General of the United Nations?
questions.ex: António Guterres is the current Secretary-General of the United Nations.

questions.q: Which international organization is responsible for maintaining international peace and security?
questions.ex: The United Nations (UN) is the primary international organization dedicated to maintaining international peace and security.

questions.q: What is the G7?
options: A group of the world's seven largest developed economies
questions.ex: The G7 is an informal bloc of seven major advanced economies.

questions.q: Which international treaty aims to combat climate change?
questions.ex: The Paris Agreement is a legally binding international treaty on climate change.

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of NATO?
questions.ex: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) is a military alliance based on the principle of collective defense.

questions.q: Which country is NOT a permanent member of the UN Security Council?
questions.ex: Germany is not a permanent member of the UN Security Council; the permanent members are China, France, Russia, the United Kingdom, and the United States.

questions.q: What is the official currency of the European Union?
questions.ex: The Euro is the official currency of the Eurozone, which consists of 20 member states of the European Union.

questions.q: Which international court is responsible for prosecuting individuals accused of genocide, war crimes, and crimes against humanity?
questions.ex: The International Criminal Court (ICC) investigates and, where warranted, tries individuals charged with the gravest crimes of concern to the international community: genocide, war crimes, crimes against humanity and the crime of aggression.

questions.q: What is the Non-Aligned Movement?
options: A group of states not formally aligned with or against any major power bloc
questions.ex: The Non-Aligned Movement is a forum of 120 developing world states that are not formally aligned with or against any major power bloc.

questions.q: Which agreement established the World Trade Organization (WTO)?
questions.ex: The World Trade Organization (WTO) was established by the Marrakesh Agreement in 1994.

questions.q: What is the UN's primary humanitarian aid agency?
questions.ex: The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) is the primary UN agency responsible for coordinating humanitarian aid.

questions.q: Which treaty ended World War I?
questions.ex: The Treaty of Versailles, signed in 1919, officially ended World War I.

questions.q: What is the main focus of the International Labour Organization (ILO)?
questions.ex: The International Labour Organization (ILO) is a United Nations agency whose mandate is to advance social justice and promote decent work by setting international labour standards.

questions.q: Which organization is responsible for international financial stability and monetary cooperation?
questions.ex: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is a major financial agency of the United Nations, and an international financial institution.

questions.q: What is the UN Human Rights Council responsible for?
questions.ex: The UN Human Rights Council is an intergovernmental body within the United Nations system responsible for strengthening the promotion and protection of human rights around the world.

questions.q: Which international agreement aims to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons?
questions.ex: The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) is a landmark international treaty whose objective is to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons and weapons technology, to promote cooperation in the peaceful uses of nuclear energy, and to further the goal of achieving nuclear disarmament.

questions.q: What is the G20?
options: A forum for international economic cooperation
questions.ex: The G20 is an international forum for the governments and central bank governors from 19 countries and the European Union.

questions.q: Which city is the headquarters of the International Criminal Court (ICC)?
questions.ex: The seat of the International Criminal Court (ICC) is in The Hague, Netherlands.

questions.q: What is the primary goal of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) set by the UN?
options: To achieve a better and more sustainable future for all
questions.ex: The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are a collection of 17 interlinked global goals designed to be a 'blueprint to achieve a better and more sustainable future for all'.

questions.q: Which organization is responsible for coordinating public health activities internationally?
questions.ex: The World Health Organization (WHO) is a specialized agency of the United Nations responsible for international public health.

questions.q: What is the term used to describe the removal of trade barriers between countries?
questions.ex: Trade liberalization is the removal or reduction of restrictions or barriers on the free exchange of goods and services between nations.

questions.q: Which international treaty governs the law of the sea?
options: Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties
United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS)
questions.ex: The United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) is an international treaty which establishes a legal framework for all marine and maritime activities.

questions.q: What is the primary function of the International Court of Justice (ICJ)?
options: To prosecute individuals for war crimes
To settle legal disputes between states
questions.ex: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) is the principal judicial organ of the United Nations and settles legal disputes between states.

questions.q: Which alliance was formed during the Cold War by the Soviet Union and its satellite states?
questions.ex: The Warsaw Pact was a collective defense treaty signed in Warsaw, Poland, between the Soviet Union and seven Eastern Bloc satellite states of Central and Eastern Europe during the Cold War.

questions.q: What is the purpose of UN peacekeeping operations?
options: To intervene in internal conflicts unilaterally
To help countries navigate the path from conflict to peace
To impose sanctions on hostile states
questions.ex: UN peacekeeping operations help countries navigate the path from conflict to peace. They are guided by three basic principles: consent of the parties, impartiality, and non-use of force, except in self-defense and defense of the mandate.

questions.q: Which international organization focuses on promoting education, science, and culture?
questions.ex: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) is a specialized agency of the United Nations aimed at promoting world peace and security through international cooperation in education, arts, sciences, and the fostering of mutual understanding.

questions.q: What is the term for the formal withdrawal of a nation from a union or political body?
questions.ex: Secession is the act of withdrawing formally from membership of a federation or body, especially a political state.

questions.q: Which international agreement aims to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases?
questions.ex: The Kyoto Protocol is an international treaty which extends the 1992 United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) that commits state parties to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

questions.q: What is the role of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)?
options: To regulate international trade in nuclear materials
To promote the peaceful use of nuclear energy and prevent its use for any military purpose
questions.ex: The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) is the world's centre for cooperation in the nuclear field, promoting the safe, secure and peaceful use of nuclear technology.

questions.q: Which organization is responsible for protecting refugees worldwide?
questions.ex: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) is a UN agency mandated to protect and support refugees at the request of a government or the UN itself.

questions.q: What does GDP stand for in economics?
questions.ex: GDP stands for Gross Domestic Product, which measures the total value of goods and services produced in a country.

questions.q: Inflation is typically measured by the change in which index?
questions.ex: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is a key measure of inflation, tracking the average change over time in the prices paid by urban consumers for a market basket of consumer goods and services.

questions.q: What is a recession defined as?
options: A period of rapid economic growth
A significant decline in economic activity spread across the economy, lasting more than a few months
A sudden increase in the stock market
questions.ex: A recession is generally defined as a significant decline in economic activity that is spread across the economy and lasts for more than a few months.

questions.q: What is the primary role of a central bank?
options: To manage a country's fiscal policy
To regulate interest rates and control the money supply
questions.ex: Central banks are responsible for monetary policy, which includes managing interest rates and controlling the money supply to influence economic conditions.

questions.q: What is the term for the total amount of money that a country's government has borrowed?
questions.ex: National debt is the accumulated total of a country's government borrowings.

questions.q: Which organization provides loans to countries for development projects?
questions.ex: The World Bank is an international financial institution that provides loans and grants to the governments of poorer countries for the purpose of pursuing capital projects.

questions.q: What is a trade surplus?
options: When a country imports more than it exports
When a country exports more than it imports
When a country's imports equal its exports
When a country has a balanced budget
questions.ex: A trade surplus occurs when the value of a country's exports exceeds the value of its imports.

questions.q: What is the main goal of monetary policy?
options: To influence the money supply and credit conditions
questions.ex: Monetary policy, managed by the central bank, aims to influence the money supply and credit conditions to achieve macroeconomic goals like price stability and full employment.

questions.q: What is fiscal policy primarily concerned with?
questions.ex: Fiscal policy involves the use of government spending and taxation to influence the economy.

questions.q: What is a common indicator of economic inequality?
questions.ex: The Gini coefficient is a measure of statistical dispersion intended to represent the income inequality or wealth inequality within a nation or any other group of people.

questions.q: What does FDI stand for in economics?
questions.ex: FDI stands for Foreign Direct Investment, which is an investment made by a firm or individual in one country into business interests located in another country.

questions.q: What is the term for a sustained decrease in the general price level of goods and services?
questions.ex: Deflation is a decrease in the general price level of goods and services.

questions.q: Which economic system is characterized by private ownership of the means of production?
questions.ex: Capitalism is an economic system in which private individuals or businesses own capital goods.

questions.q: What is the term for the value of one currency in terms of another?
questions.ex: The exchange rate is the value of one currency for the purpose of conversion to another.

questions.q: What is the primary function of the International Monetary Fund (IMF)?
options: Promoting international monetary cooperation and financial stability
questions.ex: The IMF's primary aim is to ensure the stability of the international monetary system.

questions.q: What is the term for the buying and selling of government securities in the open market?
questions.ex: Open market operations involve the central bank buying or selling government securities to influence the money supply.

questions.q: What does OPEC stand for?
options: Organization for Political and Economic Cooperation
questions.ex: OPEC is the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.

questions.q: What is a budget deficit?
questions.ex: A budget deficit occurs when government spending is greater than government revenue in a given period.

questions.q: What is the term for a tax on imported goods?
questions.ex: A tariff is a tax imposed by a government on imported goods or services.

questions.q: What is the main index tracking the performance of the New York Stock Exchange?
questions.ex: The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) is a stock market index of 30 prominent companies listed on stock exchanges in the United States.

questions.q: What is the concept of 'opportunity cost' in economics?
options: The cost of marketing a product
The value of the next best alternative forgone when a choice is made
questions.ex: Opportunity cost is the value of the next best alternative that you don't choose when you make a decision.

questions.q: What is a progressive tax system?
options: A tax system where everyone pays the same tax rate
A tax system where the tax rate decreases as income increases
A tax system where the tax rate increases as income increases
A tax system based on consumption
questions.ex: In a progressive tax system, the tax rate increases as the taxable amount increases.

questions.q: What does the term 'liquidity' refer to in finance?
options: The ease with which an asset can be converted into cash without affecting its market price
The amount of debt a company has
The total value of a company's assets
questions.ex: Liquidity refers to the efficiency or ease with which an asset can be converted into ready cash without affecting its market price.

questions.q: What is the purpose of a stock exchange?
options: To facilitate the buying and selling of stocks and other securities
questions.ex: A stock exchange is a market where securities, such as stocks and bonds, are bought and sold.

questions.q: What is a bond?
options: A share of ownership in a company
A debt instrument where an investor loans money to an entity (typically corporate or governmental) which borrows the funds for a defined period of time at a variable or fixed interest rate
questions.ex: A bond is a fixed income instrument that represents a loan made by an investor to a borrower.

questions.q: What is a central bank's discount rate?
options: The interest rate charged by commercial banks to their best customers
The interest rate at which commercial banks can borrow money directly from the central bank
The interest rate on government bonds
The interest rate on savings accounts
questions.ex: The discount rate is the interest rate charged to commercial banks and other depository institutions on loans they receive from their regional Federal Reserve Bank's lending facility—the discount window.

questions.q: What is a key characteristic of a developing economy?
options: Low levels of industrialization and infrastructure
questions.ex: Developing economies typically have lower levels of industrialization, infrastructure, and GDP per capita compared to developed economies.

questions.q: What does PPP stand for in economics when comparing economies?
questions.ex: PPP stands for Purchasing Power Parity, a theory that states that exchange rates between currencies are in equilibrium when their purchasing power is the same in each of the two countries.

questions.q: What is a stock market crash?
options: A period of steady growth in stock prices
A sudden and significant decline in stock prices across a major cross-section of a stock market
questions.ex: A stock market crash is a sudden dramatic decline of stock prices across a major cross-section of a stock market.

questions.q: What is the term for the process of a government selling state-owned assets to private entities?
questions.ex: Privatization is the transfer of ownership of property or businesses from a government to a privately owned entity.

questions.q: What is the term for a person who organizes and operates a business or businesses, taking on financial risk to do so?
questions.ex: An entrepreneur is an individual who creates a new business, bearing most of the risks and enjoying most of the rewards.

questions.q: What is the role of the World Trade Organization (WTO)?
options: To provide financial aid to developing countries
To regulate international trade and resolve trade disputes
questions.ex: The WTO is an international organization that regulates and facilitates international trade.

questions.q: What is a commodity?
options: A basic good used in commerce that is interchangeable with other goods of the same type
questions.ex: A commodity is a basic good used in commerce that is interchangeable with other goods of the same type.

questions.q: What does the term 'stagflation' describe?
options: A period of high economic growth and low inflation
A period of low economic growth, high unemployment, and high inflation
A period of deflation and low unemployment
A period of rapid technological advancement
questions.ex: Stagflation is a situation in which the inflation rate is high, the economic growth rate slows, and unemployment remains steadily high.

questions.q: What is a stock split?
options: When a company issues more shares to current shareholders, increasing the total number of outstanding shares
When a company buys back its own shares
When a company merges with another company
questions.ex: A stock split occurs when a company increases the number of its outstanding shares by issuing more shares to current shareholders, usually in proportion to their existing holdings.

questions.q: What is the central bank of Pakistan?
questions.ex: The State Bank of Pakistan is the central bank of Pakistan.

questions.q: What is the primary regulatory body for the banking sector in most countries?
questions.ex: The central bank is typically the primary regulatory body for the banking sector, overseeing monetary policy and financial stability.

questions.q: What does NASDAQ stand for?
options: National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations
North American Stock and Derivatives Alliance
New York Stock and Derivatives Automated Quotes
questions.ex: NASDAQ stands for National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations.

questions.q: What is the term for a period of declining stock prices?
questions.ex: A bear market is a period in which stock prices are generally declining.

questions.q: What is a dividend?
options: A payment made by a corporation to its shareholders
A tax imposed on financial transactions
questions.ex: A dividend is a distribution of a portion of a company's earnings to its shareholders.

questions.q: What is the term for a bank's required reserves?
options: The amount of money a bank must lend out
The percentage of deposits that banks are required to hold in reserve by the central bank
The total assets of a bank
The amount of money a bank has in its ATMs
questions.ex: Required reserves are the minimum amount of reserves that a bank must hold against its deposits as mandated by the central bank.

questions.q: What does LIBOR stand for?
questions.ex: LIBOR stood for the London Interbank Offered Rate, a benchmark interest rate (though it is being phased out).

questions.q: What is a mortgage?
options: A loan used to purchase a home or other real estate
questions.ex: A mortgage is a loan taken out to buy a house or other real estate.

questions.q: What is the term for the rate at which a central bank lends money to commercial banks?
questions.ex: The discount rate is the interest rate charged by the central bank to depository institutions that borrow short-term funds.

questions.q: What is a credit rating?
options: A measure of a person's social status
An assessment of the creditworthiness of an individual, company, or government
The number of credit cards a person has
The interest rate on a loan
questions.ex: A credit rating is an evaluation of the credit risk of a prospective debtor, predicting their ability to pay back debt.

questions.q: What is an IPO?
questions.ex: IPO stands for Initial Public Offering, the process by which a private company can go public by sale of its stock to the general public.

questions.q: What is the term for a type of investment fund that pools money from many investors to purchase securities?
questions.ex: A mutual fund is a type of investment vehicle consisting of a portfolio of stocks, bonds, or other securities.

questions.q: What is a financial bubble?
options: A period of stable economic growth
When asset prices rise rapidly and are significantly overvalued, often followed by a sharp decline
A government subsidy for a specific industry
A decrease in the money supply
questions.ex: A financial bubble occurs when asset prices are inflated to the point where they do not reflect the underlying value of the asset.

questions.q: What is cryptocurrency?
options: A type of traditional currency issued by a central bank
A digital or virtual currency that is secured by cryptography
A physical commodity used for trade
questions.ex: Cryptocurrency is a digital currency in which transactions are verified and records maintained by a decentralized system using cryptography, rather than by a centralized authority.

questions.q: What is the role of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) in the United States?
options: To oversee the stock markets and protect investors
questions.ex: The SEC is an independent federal government regulatory agency responsible for protecting investors, maintaining fair and orderly functioning of the securities markets, and facilitating capital formation.

questions.q: What is a commercial bank primarily involved in?
options: Providing loans and accepting deposits from the public
questions.ex: Commercial banks offer services to the general public and to companies, such as current, savings and deposit accounts, and they make loans to individuals and businesses.

questions.q: What is the term for the amount of interest charged on a loan?
questions.ex: The interest rate is the amount of interest due per period, as a proportion of the amount borrowed, deposited or lent (called the principal sum).

questions.q: What is a central bank's primary tool for implementing monetary policy?
questions.ex: Open market operations (buying and selling government securities) are a primary tool used by central banks to control the money supply and influence interest rates.

questions.q: What is the term for a situation where a company or individual is unable to repay their debts?
questions.ex: Insolvency is the state of being unable to pay the money owed, by a person or company, on time.

questions.q: What is the main function of a credit union?
options: To provide services only to large corporations
To provide banking and financial services to its members, who share a common bond
questions.ex: A credit union is a member-owned financial cooperative that provides banking and financial services to its members.

questions.q: What is the term for the potential of an investment to increase in value?
questions.ex: Return on investment refers to the profit or loss from an investment.

questions.q: What is the difference between a debit card and a credit card?
options: A debit card uses funds directly from a bank account, while a credit card allows borrowing funds up to a limit.
A debit card can only be used online, while a credit card can only be used in stores.
A debit card earns interest, while a credit card does not.
There is no difference between a debit card and a credit card.
questions.ex: A debit card deducts money directly from your bank account, while a credit card allows you to borrow money from the card issuer up to a certain limit.

questions.q: What is a stock market index?
options: A list of all companies traded on a stock exchange
A measure of a stock market's performance
A regulatory body for financial markets
questions.ex: A stock market index is a statistical measure of changes in the economy or financial markets.

questions.q: What is the term for borrowing money to finance an investment, often using the investment itself as collateral?
questions.ex: Leverage is the use of debt (borrowed funds) to increase the potential return of an investment.

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of a financial audit?
options: To examine a company's financial records and statements to ensure accuracy and compliance with regulations
questions.ex: A financial audit is an objective examination and evaluation of the financial statements of an organization to make sure that the financial records are a fair and accurate representation of the transactions they claim to represent.

questions.q: What is blockchain technology most famously associated with?
questions.ex: Blockchain technology is the underlying technology behind many cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin.

questions.q: What is a bond yield?
options: The face value of a bond
The annual interest rate paid on a bond
The price at which a bond is traded
The maturity date of a bond
questions.ex: Bond yield is the return an investor realizes on a bond. The most common measure is the annual interest rate paid on the bond.

questions.q: What is the function of a clearinghouse in financial markets?
options: To facilitate and verify financial transactions, reducing risk
questions.ex: A clearinghouse acts as an intermediary between buyers and sellers of financial instruments, ensuring that transactions are completed and reducing the risk of default.

questions.q: What is the term for a sudden withdrawal of deposits from a bank?
questions.ex: A bank run occurs when many clients withdraw their money from a bank, because they believe the bank may cease to function in the near future.

questions.q: What does SWIFT stand for in the banking sector?
options: Securities and Wealth International Financial Transfers
Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication
Standardized Worldwide Investment and Funding Technology
Systematic Wealth Information and Fund Tracking
questions.ex: SWIFT (Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication) is a global network that facilitates the transfer of messages about financial transactions between banks.

questions.q: What is a bailout?
options: An act of giving financial assistance to a failing business or economy to save it from collapse
questions.ex: A bailout is the provision of financial assistance to a company or country which would otherwise face bankruptcy or financial hardship.

questions.q: What is a central bank's primary goal in managing monetary policy?
options: Ensuring price stability and full employment
questions.ex: The primary goals of most central banks are to maintain price stability (control inflation) and promote full employment.

questions.q: What is the term for a market where currencies are traded?
questions.ex: The foreign exchange market (Forex) is a global decentralized or over-the-counter market for the trading of currencies.

questions.q: What is the role of a credit rating agency?
options: To assess the creditworthiness of borrowers and issue credit ratings
questions.ex: Credit rating agencies assess the creditworthiness of individuals, companies, and governments and provide credit ratings to inform investors of the risk involved in lending to them.
